sections.title: Case Particles in Classical Tibetan
sections.content: Case particles are postpositions that follow nouns to indicate their grammatical role in a sentence. Unlike English prepositions (of, to, from, in) that come before nouns, Tibetan case particles are attached after the noun. Mastering these particles is essential for reading sutras and commentaries, as they tell you the relationships between words — who did what, to whom, from where, and with what.

example.note: ཀྱི is the genitive particle linking སངས་རྒྱས to བསྟན་པ

example.transliteration: dkon mchog gsum la skyabs su mchi
example.english: I go for refuge to the Three Jewels.
example.note: ལ marks the destination/recipient of the action

example.transliteration: bla ma la skyabs su mchi
example.english: I go for refuge to the lama.
example.note: སྐྱབས་སུ uses the terminative particle སུ to mean 'as refuge'

example.english: One should be liberated from samsara.
example.note: ནས is the ablative particle meaning 'from'
འི is the genitive particle after vowel-ending words
ཀྱི is the genitive particle after བ

example.transliteration: theg pa chen po'i lam na
example.english: On the path of the Great Vehicle (Mahayana).
example.note: ན is the locative particle meaning 'in, on'

example.english: In the world, there is suffering.
example.note: ན marks the location where something exists
ཀྱི is the genitive after སེམས (ends in ས)

sections.title: Genitive Particles: གི / ཀྱི / གྱི / འི
sections.rule: Expressing possession and relationships between nouns
sections.explanation: The genitive particle means 'of' or possessive 's. It connects two nouns where the first modifies or possesses the second. The form depends on the final letter of the preceding word: གི after ད/བ/ས, ཀྱི after ག/བ with palatalization, གྱི after ད/བ with palatalization, and འི after vowel-ending words. In practice: use ཀྱི after ག/བ/ས, གི after ད/ན/མ/ར/ལ/ང, and འི after vowels.

examples.note: This pattern is ubiquitous in sutras: X ཀྱི Y = 'the Y of X'.
འི is the genitive form used after words ending in a vowel.
This phrase appears frequently in Mahayana texts discussing bodhisattva motivation.

sections.title: Dative/Locative (ལ / ན) and Ablative (ནས / ལས)
sections.rule: Indicating direction, location, source, and comparison
sections.explanation: The particle ལ marks the indirect object, direction, or purpose ('to, towards, for'). The particle ན indicates location or time ('in, at, when'). The ablative ནས means 'from' (source or starting point) and ལས can mean 'from' or 'than' (comparison). These particles are essential for understanding the relationships described in Buddhist philosophical texts.

examples.note: This homage formula opens countless Buddhist texts and prayers.

examples.english: In the world, there is suffering.
examples.note: Reflects the First Noble Truth. ན marks where something exists.
ནས marks what one is freed from — a central Buddhist concept.
ལས with འདས forms the concept of nirvana — transcending suffering.

sections.title: Associative (དང) and Terminative (སུ / རུ / ཏུ / དུ)
sections.rule: Connecting nouns and expressing purpose or transformation
sections.explanation: The particle དང connects nouns like 'and' or 'with'. It is extremely common in lists and paired concepts in sutras. The terminative particle (སུ/རུ/ཏུ/དུ) indicates purpose, direction, or transformation — 'as, into, for'. The form depends on the preceding consonant: སུ after ས/ད, རུ after ག/བ/ང/མ, ཏུ after certain consonants, and དུ as a general form.

examples.transliteration: sangs rgyas dang chos dang dge 'dun
examples.note: The Three Jewels listed with དང — the most common enumeration in Buddhist texts.

examples.english: I go for refuge / I take refuge.
examples.note: སྐྱབས་སུ་མཆི is the standard refuge formula found in all Buddhist traditions.
བྱང་ཆུབ་ཏུ་སེམས་བསྐྱེད = generating bodhicitta, a cornerstone of Mahayana practice.

sections.title: Practice Exercises
sections.description: Apply your understanding of case particles with exercises based on classical Buddhist texts

keyPoints.text: Genitive (གི/ཀྱི/གྱི/འི) means 'of' — the form depends on the final letter of the preceding word
Dative ལ marks the recipient or direction ('to, towards')
Locative ན marks location or time ('in, at, when')
Ablative ནས means 'from' (source), ལས means 'from' or 'than' (comparison)
Terminative (སུ/རུ/ཏུ/དུ) indicates purpose or transformation ('as, into, for')
